ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I learned a lot in this class and Jonathan was terrific. My one constructive criticism is that it would be helpful to have periodic homework assignments throughout the semester using cleaned up datasets to test the material.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Prof Reuning-Scherer is an excellent lecturer. The course was a thorough walk through the methods and applications of applied spatial statistics. Each class, the prior class' concepts were briefly reviewed, and then built upon. The use of R, and provision of the scripts used, helped illustrate the application of the theory. I hadn't used R at the beginning of the course, but by the end, was able to perform complex models and troubleshoot code.
Jonathan is a terrific lecturer. The TAs available in CSSI were also incredible - I learned a lot of material working one on one throughout the semester.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Students would have benefited from having a Teaching Fellow, though Prof. Reuning-Scherer was generous with his time. With a TF, we could have had more homework assignments, which I think would have helped myself and fellow procrastinators stay on top of the coursework.
Datasets for applied spatial statistics projects are very hard to find. Some help in that department might help us!

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I study Industrial Ecology. I'm not sure right at the moment how I will apply these methods since I haven't finalized my thesis topic, but I am happy to know they exist and have another set of statistical tools in my toolbox. Former colleagues at MIT had used these methods to characterize the spatial relationships of buildings and enhance models for estimating the urban heat island effect.

I was mostly interested in this course to continue gaining experience in R. I certainly got more practice but I think this course is most relevant if working with spatial data is directly relevant to your research or work interests.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took this course because: - I'd used tools like openheatmaps.com often to make chloropleths in the past, and wanted to be able to work with spatial data in custom codes -I had to take three science / math / engineering courses this semester to satisfy my degree requirements, and this one seemed interesting - I like Prof. Reuning-Scherer's teaching style

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I wasn't quite sure what to expect because I was unfamiliar with the field, but I think I had a misconception about the difference between statistics on data that happens to from different locations, and incorporating the spatial relationshops into statistics analyses.
Yes, I certainly learned a lot but wish we'd had more homework during the semester just to keep building experience working in R.
Yes. However, it is very theoretical and requires more than a little understanding of R. They should definitely have more stringent prerequisites for this course.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Team work is greater because this course provides coding challenges that could keep in your stuck in one place forever.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I would recommend that they follow the course guidance, and find a dataset early, and attempt to apply the methods learned to the dataset. Also, following the course guidance and practicing the with the provided R scripts and data is useful way to learn.

Find a few datasets early in the semester and do work on them throughout. Not all of the techniques are applicable to every type of data but it's helpful to work through more than just Jonathan's scripts since 99% of the battle is dealing with the vagaries of spatial data.
Come to this course only if you have intermediate levels of experience with R.
